resource.chars:
Note cont..
has designated as <u>Orbitoides dispansa</u> and <u>Orbitoides fortisi</u>, the
bodies which, in the account of them he had previously given in the
"Mem Soc Géol de France" 2nd Sér, Vol III he had designated as
Orbitolites; thus correcting the error into which M Carter had
fallen in his description of the same Fossils; through reliance
on M D'Orbigny's insufficient and indeed erroneous characters
of these genera]
_________ _ Around the nucleus which occupies the centre of the
disk (Plate II, Figs 1, 2,<s>)? Plate Fig)</s> Plate III, Fig.1.) are seen an indeterminate number
of concentric zones of cells (<u>@,@,@</u>) the shape of which differs in different
individuals (see Sect. IV); these, although completely closed (unless laid
open by abrasion), <s>being</s> have their form distinctly indicated by the surface-markings. The
only external orifices which communicate with these cells, are the minute
pores (<u>d,d,d,</u>) forming one or more ranges at the margin of the disk, each
pore lying in a vertical furrow between the projecting walls of two
contiguous cells. In the smallest and thinnest disks (Plate II, Fig 1, 5, Plate X, Fig. 2), we find but a
single row, or sometimes two rows, (Plate II, Fig 7) of such pores; in disks somewhat
thicker, there are three or four rows; and in the largest and thickest
Orbitolites (Plate III, Fig. 1), no fewer than ten or twelve such rows. This multiplication
